result.adr_address: Pai Tau Street 311地段, Sha Tin, Hong Kong
result.formatted_address: Pai Tau Street 311地段, Sha Tin, Hong Kong
result.name: Po Fook Hill Cemetery

reviews.text: Very hot this day. There are escalators halfway to the top. Great view.

Like other tourists, I came here by mistake thinking it was the entrance to the temple of the 10,000 Bhuddas. It is in fact a typical Chinese cemetery where locals go to visit their defunct relatives. The cemetery is really large and built along the sides of the hill. It is really well looked after and you have escalators to reach the summit, along which you can see monkeys.
If your intention is to see the temple instead, my advice is to look well at the maps in advance and to avoid following the stream of local people on a Sunday, who are going to see their dead relatives. The entrance to the temple starts with golden statues of Buddha from the very entrance rather than the white gate shown in the following pictures.
Chinese style of cemetery building, good to observe the spirit of how they respecting the passaway family members.  Much cultural shocks and foundings you can discover here.
Not picturesque for tourists, but good for visiting dead relatives.

Went here by mistake thinking it was the 10K Bhudda place.  It’s actually a funeral home, lots of buildings linked together on a strop hill and connected by stairways.  Each building is the size of a small house and contains just one room.  Every inch of wall space, floor to roof, is used to commemorate deceased.  Some can afford A4 size plaques with photos, others are tiny playing card sized shrines.  It’s still in regular use, very interesting and glad we stumbled across it.  If you’re going to 10K then you might as well have a look here too.
